msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
William Lewis Sharkey belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located between Maryland & Virginia on the Potomac River, the Territory of Columbia was established on July 16, 1790 under the name Federal City and was renamed Washington City in the 1800s. The city of Washington became the federal capital on February 27, 1801 and established as Washington, D.C. on February 24, 1801, when the city boundaries were expanded to include the entire Federal District of Columbia. Washington, D.C. has never achieved statehood. (Wikipedia, Britannica)
The Territory of Nebraska was established May 30, 1854. Admitted as the 37th state, Nebraska achieved statehood March 1, 1867. (Britannica; Wikipedia)

Located in Warren County, Mississippi, Vicksburg was founded under the name Fort Nogales as early as 1790 in what was then unincorporated territory. In 1798, upon creation of Mississippi Territory, it was renamed Walnut Hills. On April 1, 1799, Walnut Hills became part of the newly created Pickering County (later renamed Jefferson County on January 10, 1802), until the creation of Claiborne County on January 26, 1802. It then became part of its current county of Warren on December 21, 1809. Upon its incorporation on January 29th, 1825, it was renamed Vicksburg. Vicksburg became the county seat in 1836 and remains today. (Rowland, Mississippi, 858; Wikipedia; Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Occupations -- Financial Occupations
Occupations -- Professional Labor

gloss.p: "A person who works for one or more companies finding business for them; a person whose job is to sell land and buildings which are used for business activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone who sells land and receives a part of the money paid for the goods for doing this."

"A person whose job is to design or build machines, engines, or electrical equipment, or things such as roads, railroads, or bridges, using scientific principles." Alternatively, "an engineer is also a person whose job is to drive railroad trains." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official who has the legal authority to say that documents are correctly signed or true or to make an oath (= promise) official." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America--Army Corps of Engineers
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- C.S.A. Federal Government
Organizations -- Military Organizations

gloss.p: The Provisional Confederate Congress established the Army Corps of Engineers (Confederate) on March 6, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama under the War Department. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, the Corps of Engineers was responsible for the construction of military fortifications and buildings, bridges, and demolitions in the Confederate Army. (Acts and Resolutions of the First Session of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861 Public Laws, S1, 9; Wikipedia)

term.rs: Confederate States of America--Army Corps of Engineers

gloss.p: Operating at the national level, the United States Department of the Interior was created in 1849 and located in Washington, D.C. It is one of the executive departments of the U.S. federal government and responsible for the management and conservation of most federal lands and natural resources; the administration of programs relating to Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, territorial affairs, and insular areas of the United States; and programs related to historic preservation. (Wikipedia)

Operating at the national level, the General Land Office was an independent agency of the United States government responsible for public domain lands in the United States. It was created in 1812 and located in Washington, D.C. to take over functions previously conducted by the United States Department of the Treasury.(Wikipedia)

div.p:
Honl W L Sharkey
Governor of Mississippi

I take the liberty of enclosing to you a letter to me from my son in law George Donnellan. Mr Donnellan filled an important place in the Dept of the Interior at Washington and subsequently was Register of the Land Office Nebraska. he is also a licenced lawyer. he served du-ring the war in C. S. Engineer Corps.

He wishes to go into business in Vicksburg at once as a commissioner of deeds. Conveyances Engineer & General Agent. I can vouch for his integrity of character & his excellent capacity for business I will feel greatly obliged to you for your permission to use your name on his cards, at the head of his referrences and also to commission him as a notary pub-lic & commissioner of deeds. I am sure he will not give you any cause to regret your kindness. & I will feel grateful to you for the favor
M. G. Mauhel requests permission to use the Governors name as a reference on the business cards of his son in law
